title: Indices and Surds
content:
Module 2, Lesson 8: Indices and Surds

The Hook

Indices (exponents) and surds (irrational square roots and nth roots) are fundamental algebraic tools. Surds like √2, √3, and ∛5 arise constantly in geometry, physics, and engineering. Manipulating them in exact form (rationalising, simplifying) is an important algebraic skill.

The Concept

1. Laws of Indices

aᵐ × aⁿ = aᵐ⁺ⁿ; (aᵐ)ⁿ = aᵐⁿ; aᵐ/aⁿ = aᵐ⁻ⁿ; a⁰ = 1; a⁻ⁿ = 1/aⁿ; a^(p/q) = (ᵠ√a)ᵖ. These are the tools for simplifying all exponential expressions.

2. Simplifying Surds

√(ab) = √a × √b; √(a/b) = √a/√b. Simplify by factoring out perfect squares: √48 = √(16 × 3) = 4√3. Like surds can be combined: 3√2 + 5√2 = 8√2.

3. Rationalising the Denominator

To eliminate surds from a denominator: for 1/√a, multiply by √a/√a. For 1/(a + √b), multiply by the conjugate (a – √b)/(a – √b), using the difference of squares identity (a + b)(a – b) = a² – b².

4. Fractional Indices

aᵖ/ᵠ = (ᵠ√a)ᵖ = ᵠ√(aᵖ). So 8^(2/3) = (∛8)² = 2² = 4. Fractional indices unify the treatment of roots and powers.

The Illustration

You practised all laws of indices, simplified surds, rationalised denominators, and used fractional indices. These skills are prerequisites for calculus and allow exact rather than approximate calculation.
